citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, a female, cinnamon-colored black bear, approximately 18 months old, was showing abnormal
behaviors while moving around the enclosure that served no obvious purpose. Especially while walking straight toward
the fence or pacing along the fence, she would suddenly stop moving forward, throw her nose straight into the air, and
abruptly change her direction of movement. The behavior was seen frequently between periods of play, scratching,
foraging for apples, and moving around the enclosure, and occurred as often as 3 directional changes in 20 seconds
when observed. The behavior was more pronounced during warmer weather and when there were many visitors around.
The abnormal directional change was observed both away from the fence and along the fence, even when there were no
visitors with apples in the area. Space did not appear to be a factor as she is housed in a large outdoor enclosure with
plenty of space to roam, elevation changes, climbing structures and a waterfall/pond. The facility representative was
aware of this abnormal behavior, but no changes have been made to decrease the signs of stress that the bear is
showing. Additionally, the attending veterinarian had not been notified of the abnormal behaviors of the animal and
veterinary care has not been provided to evaluate the bear’s physical and mental health.
Daily observation of all animals shall be made to assess their health and well-being and promptly identify injuries,
disease, and other medical conditions. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
Untreated injuries, infections, and other conditions can be painful and cause suffering to the animal, and frequent
communications with the attending veterinarian are required to allow for the veterinarian to advise licensees on needed
treatments for health concerns, which helps to mitigate the effects of adverse health conditions. Correct by ensuring that
this female yearling bear, and any other bears showing abnormal behaviors, are evaluated by a veterinarian and that
treatments and care instructions are followed as prescribed.
***Correct by 6pm Eastern time on Friday 7/18/25.

The facility is feeding the cubs, yearlings, and adult black bears a mixed diet consisting of produce, meats, restaurant
food scraps, bakery items, and some sweet treats. Some of the bears appear overconditioned for the current time of year
suggesting that the diet may need to be adjusted. When consulting with the attending veterinarian, they were unaware of
the content and amount of food being provided to the bears. Additionally, during the inspection, four 52-pound unopened
bags and 2 bags in use were identified with a "best by" date of 10/21/22. Long outdated food may not be of sufficient
nutritive value for the animals, and feeding a diet too high in calories, sugar, and fat can cause obesity in the bears. The
food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain
all animals in good health. The diet shall be prepared with consideration for the age, species, condition, size, and type of
the animal. Animals shall be fed at least once a day except as dictated by hibernation, veterinary treatment, normal fasts,
or other professionally accepted practices.
***Correct by 8/15/25.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
